body_content.explanation: to go past something or someone or move in relation to it, him, or her:
examples: I passed him on the stairs this morning.
You should only pass a slower vehicle if it is safe to do so.
If you pass a supermarket, could you get me some milk?
I was just passing by (= going past the place where you are), so I thought I'd drop in for a chat.
A momentary look of anxiety passed across his face.
A cloud passed over the sun.

body_content.explanation: to go past a particular point in time:
examples: Don't buy goods that have passed their sell-by date.

body_content.explanation: to go past something by being greater in amount or degree:
examples: The company's turnover is expected to pass the $10 million mark by the end of this year.

body_content.explanation: If you say a state or feeling will pass, you mean it will disappear:
examples: Don't worry, his depression is only temporary - it'll soon pass.

body_content.explanation: to be successful in an exam, course, etc.:
examples: Guess what? I've passed my driving test!
The exam is so hard that only five percent of all applicants pass.

body_content.explanation: to give something to someone:
examples: Could you pass the salt please?
I asked if I could see the letter, so she passed it to me reluctantly.
Gerald passed me the note./Gerald passed the note to me.
Genes are the means by which parents' characteristics are passed on to their children.

body_content.explanation: In sports, if you pass the ball, you kick, throw, or hit it to someone in your team.
If you pass money, you give someone false or stolen money without telling them:
examples: I haven't trusted him since he passed me a forged $100 bill.
She was arrested for passing stolen cheques.

body_content.explanation: When time passes, it goes past:
examples: Time seems to pass (by) so slowly when you're bored.
I was a little worried about the party, but the evening passed without any great disasters.

body_content.explanation: If you pass a period of time, you do something to stop yourself being bored during that period:
examples: The visitors pass their days swimming, windsurfing, and playing volleyball.

body_content.explanation: (of an official group of people) to give approval to something, especially by voting to make it law:
examples: The government passed a law to restrict the sale of guns.
The food supplement had been passed as safe for human consumption.

body_content.explanation: to express a judgment or opinion about something, especially someone else's behaviour:
examples: As a convicted criminal, he's in no position to pass judgment (on the rest of us).

body_content.explanation: to say officially, as a judge, what a criminal's official punishment will be
to die:
examples: After she passed, the doctors wanted to do an autopsy.
His wife was at his side when he passed peacefully this morning.

body_content.explanation: to remove waste from the body:
examples: to pass urine

body_content.explanation: to have blood in your urine or faeces (= solid waste):
examples: If you pass blood, you should go and see your doctor.

body_content.explanation: to choose not to play in a part of a game or not to answer a question in a quiz
to change from one state to another:
examples: Wax passes from solid to liquid when you heat it.

body_content.explanation: a successful result in an exam:
examples: Jon Hill achieved two grade A passes at A-level.

body_content.explanation: a successful result in a course or exam for which the student will not be given a mark:
examples: I got a pass in my Literature course.

body_content.explanation: a movement of the ball from one player to another member of the same team in a team sport
an official document or ticket showing that you have the right to go somewhere or use a particular form of transport:
examples: a bus pass
a boarding pass
My guest pass allows me to use the club's facilities free of charge.

body_content.explanation: a document that allows a student to leave a class for a particular reason:
examples: She had a pass to go to the library.

body_content.explanation: a path or road between or over mountains:
examples: a mountain pass

body_content.explanation: an occasion when someone reads through a text, especially in order to edit it (= make changes to it):
examples: I'm now doing my editing pass on the document.
Don't try to memorize everything. Don't try to get every detail on the first pass.

body_content.explanation: a difficult or unpleasant condition:
examples: If I'd been aware things had reached such a pass, I'd have told the police.
It's come to a pretty pass (= it's a bad situation) when you can't even have a few quiet drinks with some friends.

body_content.explanation: to speak to or touch someone in a way that shows you would like to start a sexual relationship with them
